The Right Honorable the Governor in Council announces with the deepest concern, the receipt of intelligence from England, communicating the demise, on the 2nd December 1849, in the 58th year of her age, of Her Most Gracious Majesty, the Queen Dowager. 2- His Lordship in Council directs, that the Flag at the Castle be hoisted Half-Mast-High at Sunrise, so to continue until Sunset; and that Minute Guns to the number of 57, cor responding in number with the age of Her late Majesty, be fired from the Saluting Battery at Noon. 3. His Lordship in Council directs, that similar honors be paid to the memory of Her la mented Majesty by the Vessels of the Indian Navy ; the firing of the Minute. Guns from the Ships to commence as soon as the Guns from the Garrison shall have ceased, and to be con tinued under such arrangements as the Commander in Chief of the Indian Navy may direct. 4. Similar marks of respect are to be paid on receipt of this order, at every principal Military Station subordinate to this Government. 5. His Lordship in Council is further pleased to direct, that mourning be worn by the Offi - cersof Her Majesty's and the Hon'ble Company's Civil, Military, and Naval Services of this Presidency, for a period of six weeks from this date; a mark of respect which he confidently . anticipates will be generally paid by the other portions of the Community, in manifestation of feelings of mournful regret for the death ofthis^most illustrious and universally regretted Personage, whose eminent virtues and exemplary piety have endeared her to all classes. By order of the Right lion ble the Governor in Council, A. MALET, Chief Secy, to Govt, S&r , .

titleInfo.title: Letter No. 184: Arthur Malet, Chief Secretary to Government at Bombay, to Samuel Hennell, Resident in the Persian Gulf, Bushire

mods.abstract: In this letter, received by Samuel Hennell on 27 March 1850, Arthur Malet writes that he has been directed by the Governor in Council to transmit a copy of a notification issued by the Government announcing the death on 2 December 1849 of the Queen Dowager. Attached is a printed extraordinary notification, also dated 15 January 1850, announcing the death of the Queen Dowager and giving instructions regarding mourning and marks of respect.
